   Other labs:

   ALT / AST:19/51, Alk Phos / T Bili:97/2.7,
   Differential-Neuts:77.9 %, Lymph:15.9 %, Mono:5.3 %, Eos:0.6 %,
   Ca++:8.6 mg/dL, Mg++:2.3 mg/dL, PO4:4.7 mg/dL
   Micro: blood cx from [**1-8**], [**1-9**]: pending
   Urine cx from [**1-8**]: pending
   Assessment and Plan
   24 yo M with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to CCU after failure
   to extubate s/p elective AICD placement and right heart cath.
   .
   # Failure to extubate: Patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU
   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization on
   [**1-8**]. Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid
   obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume
   overload from patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading
   to elevated elastic pressures. ABG initially showed chronic respiratory
   acidosis with appropriate metabolic compensation, may be due to obesity
   hypoventilation/Pickwickian syndrome, but repeat ABG showed normal
   gas.  Initially pt was diuresed with lasix gtt (40 mg IV bolus x1),
   which was held in the setting of hypotension and poor UOP.  Patient was
   put on Assist Control throughout the night here in CCU, and PEEP was
   down-titrated from 12 to 8 with good oxygenation.
   - change from AC to pressure support
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - wean ventilator as tolerated
   - start lasix diuresis once pt is off pressor
   - attempt to extubate this am
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After arriving on
   the CCU floor, non-invasive approach revealed BP in the 90-100s/40s.
   However, patient had no UOP to lasix bolus and gtt, so A-line was
   placed. Placement of A-line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating relative
   hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical ventilation which
   are more likely given the acute change versus sepsis given recent
   diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of keflex, fever noted on
   CCU admission, hypotension, and decreased urine output.  Patient was
   started on neo gtt for MAP>65.  Lasix gtt was held. PEEP was turned
   down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.
   - turn off neo this morning and see if pt can maintain BP on his own
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - extubate today if possible
   - hold placement of CVL for now given possible extubation this AM; will
   place if pressor requirements increase.
   - f/u blood and urine cultures
   - check  c. diff toxin assay
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cre up to 1.7 on admission and up to 2.1 this AM
   (baseline 1.1).  Patient relatively oliguric on admission to the CCU
   with only 40 ccs of dark urine output to 20 of IV lasix administered in
   the PACU.   After lasix gtt was started last night, UOP was close to
   zero.  After neo was started, UOP finally picked up after a few hours.
   At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most likely pre-renal in setting of
   hypotension during the procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to
   ATN (intrarenal).  FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other
   etiologies (though less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of
   depressed EF% versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent
   contrast administration.
   - turn off neo and see if he can maintain BP on his own
   - renal consult this AM
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4
   overnight. Likely febrile in setting of recent procedure. Hypotension,
   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning
   for possible sepsis.  UA is negative.
   - f/u blood cultures, urine cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Hyperbilirubinemia: Long-standing but bilirubin is very high at 2.7
   this am. Etiologies include [**Doctor Last Name **] syndrome, fatty liver and biliary
   stasis, CHF and biliary stasis, acalculous cholecystitis, gallstone
   cholecystitis. Patient sedated with propofol overnight given quick
   on/off for sedation. Patient received fentanyl and versed but was
   reportedly not well sedated during the procedure on this regimen,
   resulting in switch to propofol. Per discussion with pharmacy, OK to
   sedate with propofol temporarily overnight (12 hours) if extubation
   planned this AM.
   - f/u on direct and indirect bili
   - consider RUQ US
   - trend LFTs daily
   .
   # PUMP: Non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, thought to be viral in
   etiology. Likely has chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure (EF
   25% on [**9-28**].) Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC
   today with severe pulmonary hypertension. Patient received lasix 20 mg
   IV x1 in PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then
   held in the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were
   ~20 pts lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output.
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - fluid restriction, low Na diet, strict Is and Os, foley, daily
   weights
   - continue BB, digoxin
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient is s/p AICD placement for primary prevention of
   tachyarrythmias given non-ischemic cardiomyopathy EF of 25%. One
   episode of NSVT in the CCU.  Dig level 0.9 this am.
   - will need PA/lateral CXR once pt is extubated to check lead position
   - EP to interrogate pacer in AM
   - replete K > 4 Mg > 2
   - continue beta-blocker and digoxin
   .
   # CORONARIES: No known hx of CAD.
   - continue ASA, beta-blocker
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] in setting acute renal failure
   .
   # Asthma:
   - albuterol inhaler prn
   .
   # Anemia: Known iron deficiency anemia.
   - Trend Hct.
   - Continue iron supplements with bowel regimen and vitamin C once able
   to take PO.
   .
   # OSA:
   - restart/encourage nocturnal CPAP at home once extubated.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NPO for now
   Glycemic Control:  not on insulin
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2193-1-8**] 10:00 PM
   18 Gauge - [**2193-1-8**] 10:56 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2193-1-9**] 02:03 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Need for restraints reviewed
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the ICU after failure to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He is currently intubated and ventilated, with a fever of 101.4Â°F, hypotension, and acute renal failure. His laboratory results show elevated creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, and bilirubin levels. He has a history of iron deficiency anemia and is on iron supplements. His cardiovascular system is compromised, with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25% and severe pulmonary hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, hypotension, and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of sepsis.
2. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels indicate AKI, which may be due to pre-renal causes such as hypotension, or post-renal causes such as urinary tract obstruction.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's chronic respiratory acidosis and need for mechanical ventilation suggest the possibility of respiratory failure.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's non-ischemic cardiomyopathy and severe pulmonary hypertension may lead to cardiac complications such as cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiogenic shock.
5. Infection: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of infection, which may be related to the recent procedure or underlying medical conditions.
6. Malnutrition: The patient's history of iron deficiency anemia and need for nutrition support suggest the possibility of malnutrition.
7. Venous Thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's immobility and underlying medical conditions increase his risk of VTE.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's assessment and plan should focus on addressing his underlying medical conditions, managing his symptoms, and preventing complications. This may include:

* Continuation of mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to manage his respiratory failure
* Administration of antibiotics to treat potential infections
* Management of his cardiac condition, including diuretics, vasodilators, and anti-arrhythmic medications
* Nutrition support, including total parenteral nutrition (TPN) or enteral nutrition, to manage his malnutrition
* Prevention of VTE with low-molecular-weight heparin or unfractionated heparin
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis, AKI, and cardiac complications, and adjusting therapy as necessary.

   Assessment and Plan
   24 yo M with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to CCU after failure
   to extubate s/p elective AICD placement and right heart cath.
   .
   # Failure to extubate: Patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU
   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization on
   [**1-8**]. Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid
   obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume
   overload from patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading
   to elevated elastic pressures. ABG initially showed chronic respiratory
   acidosis with appropriate metabolic compensation, may be due to obesity
   hypoventilation/Pickwickian syndrome, but repeat ABG showed normal
   gas.  Initially pt was diuresed with lasix gtt (40 mg IV bolus x1),
   which was held in the setting of hypotension and poor UOP.  Patient was
   put on Assist Control throughout the night here in CCU, and PEEP was
   down-titrated from 12 to 8 with good oxygenation.
   - change from AC to pressure support
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - wean ventilator as tolerated
   - start lasix diuresis once pt is off pressor
   - attempt to extubate this am
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After arriving on
   the CCU floor, non-invasive approach revealed BP in the 90-100s/40s.
   However, patient had no UOP to lasix bolus and gtt, so A-line was
   placed. Placement of A-line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating relative
   hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical ventilation which
   are more likely given the acute change, sepsis given recent diagnosis
   of cellulitis treated with 10 days of keflex, fever noted on CCU
   admission, or cardiogenic which are less likely given the acute time
   course of events, i.e., his BP was good prior to the procedure.
   Patient was started on neo gtt for MAP>65.  Lasix gtt was held. PEEP
   was turned down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.
   - turn off neo this morning and see if pt can maintain BP on his own
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - extubate today if possible
   - hold placement of CVL for now given possible extubation this AM; will
   place if pressor requirements increase.
   - f/u blood and urine cultures
   - check  c. diff toxin assay
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cre up to 1.7 on admission and up to 2.1 this AM
   (baseline 1.1).  Patient relatively oliguric on admission to the CCU
   with only 40 ccs of dark urine output to 20 of IV lasix administered in
   the PACU.   After lasix gtt was started last night, UOP was close to
   zero.  After neo was started, UOP finally picked up after a few hours.
   At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most likely pre-renal in setting of
   hypotension during the procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to
   ATN (intrarenal).  FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other
   etiologies (though less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of
   depressed EF% versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent
   contrast administration.
   - turn off neo and see if he can maintain BP on his own
   - renal consult this AM
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4
   overnight. Likely febrile in setting of recent procedure. Hypotension,
   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning
   for possible sepsis.  UA is negative.
   - f/u blood cultures, urine cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Hyperbilirubinemia: Long-standing but bilirubin is very high at 2.7
   this am. Etiologies include [**Doctor Last Name **] syndrome, fatty liver and biliary
   stasis, CHF and biliary stasis, acalculous cholecystitis, gallstone
   cholecystitis. Patient sedated with propofol overnight given quick
   on/off for sedation. Patient received fentanyl and versed but was
   reportedly not well sedated during the procedure on this regimen,
   resulting in switch to propofol. Per discussion with pharmacy, OK to
   sedate with propofol temporarily overnight (12 hours) if extubation
   planned this AM.
   - f/u on direct and indirect bili
   - consider RUQ US
   - trend LFTs daily
   .
   # PUMP: Non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, thought to be viral in
   etiology. Likely has chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure (EF
   25% on [**9-28**].) Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC
   today with severe pulmonary hypertension. Patient received lasix 20 mg
   IV x1 in PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then
   held in the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were
   ~20 pts lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output.
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - fluid restriction, low Na diet, strict Is and Os, foley, daily
   weights
   - continue BB, digoxin
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient is s/p AICD placement for primary prevention of
   tachyarrythmias given non-ischemic cardiomyopathy EF of 25%. One
   episode of NSVT in the CCU.  Dig level 0.9 this am.
   - will need PA/lateral CXR once pt is extubated to check lead position
   - EP to interrogate pacer in AM
   - replete K > 4 Mg > 2
   - continue beta-blocker and digoxin
   .
   # CORONARIES: No known hx of CAD.
   - continue ASA, beta-blocker
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] in setting acute renal failure
   .
   # Asthma:
   - albuterol inhaler prn
   .
   # Anemia: Known iron deficiency anemia.
   - Trend Hct.
   - Continue iron supplements with bowel regimen and vitamin C once able
   to take PO.
   .
   # OSA:
   - restart/encourage nocturnal CPAP at home once extubated.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NPO for now
   Glycemic Control:  not on insulin
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2193-1-8**] 10:00 PM
   18 Gauge - [**2193-1-8**] 10:56 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2193-1-9**] 02:03 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Need for restraints reviewed

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the ICU after failure to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. The patient has a history of systolic and diastolic heart failure, and was found to have chronic respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation, likely due to obesity hypoventilation syndrome. The patient was diagnosed with acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.7 on admission and 2.1 this morning, and is oliguric with only 40cc of dark urine output. The patient also has a fever, with a temperature of 101.4, and has been treated with antibiotics for cellulitis. The patient is receiving lasix diuresis, and is being monitored for signs of sepsis.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level is increasing, and the patient is oliguric, which may indicate AKI.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory acidosis and obesity hypoventilation syndrome make him susceptible to respiratory failure, which can lead to respiratory arrest.
4. Cardiac failure: The patient's non-ischemic cardiomyopathy and chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure make him susceptible to cardiac failure, which can lead to cardiogenic shock.
5. Hepatic dysfunction: The patient's elevated bilirubin level and liver function tests suggest the possibility of hepatic dysfunction, which can lead to coagulopathy and bleeding.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's elevated creatinine level and oliguria suggest the possibility of electrolyte imbalance, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
7. Infection: The patient's cellulitis and fever suggest the possibility of infection, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's chronic liver disease and elevated bilirubin level make him susceptible to gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hemodynamic instability.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely for signs of sepsis, AKI, and respiratory failure.
2. Continue to manage the patient's cardiac failure with diuretics and vasopressors as needed.
3. Monitor the patient's liver function tests and bilirubin level to assess for hepatic dysfunction.
4. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and correct any imbalances promptly.
5. Continue to manage the patient's cellulitis with antibiotics and monitor for signs of infection.
6. Consider performing a renal ultrasound to assess for any underlying renal pathology.
7. Consider performing a liver biopsy to assess for any underlying liver disease.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as needed.

   Assessment and Plan
   24 yo M with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to CCU after failure
   to extubate s/p elective AICD placement and right heart cath.
   .
   # Failure to extubate: Patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU
   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization on
   [**1-8**]. Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid
   obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume
   overload from patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading
   to elevated elastic pressures. ABG initially showed chronic respiratory
   acidosis with appropriate metabolic compensation, may be due to obesity
   hypoventilation/Pickwickian syndrome, but repeat ABG showed normal
   gas.  Initially pt was diuresed with lasix gtt (40 mg IV bolus x1),
   which was held in the setting of hypotension and poor UOP.  Patient was
   put on Assist Control throughout the night here in CCU, and PEEP was
   down-titrated from 12 to 8 with good oxygenation.
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - wean ventilator as tolerated
   - start lasix diuresis once pt is off pressor
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After arriving on
   the CCU floor, non-invasive approach revealed BP in the 90-100s/40s.
   However, patient had no UOP to lasix bolus and gtt, so A-line was
   placed. Placement of A-line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating relative
   hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical ventilation versus
   sepsis given recent diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of
   keflex, fever noted on CCU admission, hypotension, and decreased urine
   output.  Patient was started on neo gtt for MAP>65.  Lasix gtt was
   held. PEEP was turned down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.
   - turn off neo this morning and see if pt can maintain BP on his own
   - extubate today if possible
   - hold placement of CVL for now given possible extubation this AM; will
   place if pressor requirements increase.
   - f/u blood and urine cultures
   - check  c. diff toxin assay
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cre up to 1.7 on admission and up to 2.1 this AM
   (baseline 1.1).  Patient relatively oliguric on admission to the CCU
   with only 40 ccs of dark urine output to 20 of IV lasix administered in
   the PACU.   After lasix gtt was started last night, UOP was close to
   zero.  After neo was started, UOP finally picked up after a few hours.
   At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most likely pre-renal in setting of
   hypotension during the procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to
   ATN (intrarenal).  FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other
   etiologies (though less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of
   depressed EF% versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent
   contrast administration.
   - turn off neo and see if he can maintain BP on his own
   - renal consult this AM
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4
   overnight. Likely febrile in setting of recent procedure. Hypotension,
   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning
   for possible sepsis.  UA is negative.
   - f/u blood cultures, urine cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Hyperbilirubinemia: Long-standing but bilirubin is very high at 2.7
   this am. Etiologies include [**Doctor Last Name **] syndrome, fatty liver and biliary
   stasis, CHF and biliary stasis, acalculous cholecystitis, gallstone
   cholecystitis. Patient sedated with propofol overnight given quick
   on/off for sedation. Patient received fentanyl and versed but was
   reportedly not well sedated during the procedure on this regimen,
   resulting in switch to propofol. Per discussion with pharmacy, OK to
   sedate with propofol temporarily overnight (12 hours) if extubation
   planned this AM.
   - f/u on direct and indirect bili
   - consider RUQ US
   - trend LFTs daily
   .
   # PUMP: Non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, thought to be viral in
   etiology. Likely has chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure (EF
   25% on [**9-28**].) Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC
   today with severe pulmonary hypertension. Patient received lasix 20 mg
   IV x1 in PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then
   held in the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were
   ~20 pts lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output.
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - fluid restriction, low Na diet, strict Is and Os, foley, daily
   weights
   - continue BB, digoxin
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient is s/p AICD placement for primary prevention of
   tachyarrythmias given non-ischemic cardiomyopathy EF of 25%. One
   episode of NSVT in the CCU.  Dig level 0.9 this am.
   - will need PA/lateral CXR once pt is extubated to check lead position
   - EP to interrogate pacer in AM
   - replete K > 4 Mg > 2
   - continue beta-blocker and digoxin
   .
   # CORONARIES: No known hx of CAD.
   - continue ASA, beta-blocker
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] in setting acute renal failure
   .
   # Asthma:
   - albuterol inhaler prn
   .
   # Anemia: Known iron deficiency anemia.
   - Trend Hct.
   - Continue iron supplements with bowel regimen and vitamin C once able
   to take PO.
   .
   # OSA:
   - restart/encourage nocturnal CPAP at home once extubated.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NPO for now
   Glycemic Control:  not on insulin
   Lines:

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the ICU after an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization procedure. He was unable to be extubated in the PACU due to extrapulmonary restriction and poor lung compliance. The patient has a history of chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure, and was diagnosed with acute renal failure, hyperbilirubinemia, and anemia.

Progress:

The patient was started on invasive ventilation and an arterial line was placed due to hypotension. He was given lasix IV and a gtt, but had no urine output, so the gtt was held. The patient was started on neo gtt for blood pressure support. His blood pressure responded well to the neo, and PEEP was decreased from 12 to 8 to help with blood pressure.

The patient's urine output initially was 30cc/hr, but picked up to 250cc/hr after neo was started. His creatinine levels are elevated, indicating acute renal failure. The patient has a high bilirubin level, and is at risk for acute liver failure.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's current condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring. The plan is to wean him off the ventilator and propofol, and to start diuresis once he is off the pressor. The patient's blood and urine cultures are pending, and he will be followed up with a renal consult.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's lung compliance is poor, and he is at risk for developing ARDS.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever, hypotension, and decreased urine output suggest that he may be septic.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and he is at risk for developing AKI.
4. Liver Failure: The patient's high bilirubin level suggests that he may be at risk for developing liver failure.
5. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he is at risk for developing cardiac arrest.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation closely.
2. Wean the patient off the ventilator and propofol as tolerated.
3. Start diuresis once the patient is off the pressor.
4. Follow up with a renal consult to discuss further management of the patient's acute renal failure.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and consider further evaluation if his bilirubin levels continue to rise.
6. Consider a cardiac consult to discuss further management of the patient's cardiac function.

   Assessment and Plan
   24 yo M with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to CCU after failure
   to extubate s/p elective AICD placement and right heart cath.
   .
   # Failure to extubate: Patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU
   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization.
   Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid obesity/large
   body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume overload from
   patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading to elevated
   elastic pressures. ABG initially showed chronic respiratory acidosis
   with appropriate metabolic compensation, may be due to obesity
   hypoventilation/Pickwickian syndrome, but repeat ABG showed normal
   gas.  Initially pt was diuresed with lasix gtt (40 mg IV bolus x1),
   which was held in the setting of hypotension and poor UOP.  Patient was
   put on Assist Control throughout the night here in CCU, and PEEP was
   down-titrated from 12 to 8 with good oxygenation.
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - wean ventilator as tolerated
   - start lasix diuresis once pt is off pressor
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After arriving on
   the CCU floor, non-invasive approach revealed BP in the 90-100s/40s.
   However, patient had no UOP to lasix bolus and gtt, so A-line was
   placed. Placement of A-line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating relative
   hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical ventilation versus
   sepsis given recent diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of
   keflex, fever noted on CCU admission, hypotension, and decreased urine
   output.  Patient was started on neo gtt for MAP>65.  Lasix gtt was
   held. PEEP was turned down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.
   - turn off neo this morning and see if pt can maintain BP on his own
   - extubate today if possible
   - hold placement of CVL for now given possible extubation this AM; will
   place if pressor requirements increase.
   - f/u blood and urine cultures
   - check  c. diff toxin assay
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cre up to 1.7 on admission and up to 2.1 this AM
   (baseline 1.1).  Patient relatively oliguric on admission to the CCU
   with only 40 ccs of dark urine output to 20 of IV lasix administered in
   the PACU.   After lasix gtt was started last night, UOP was close to
   zero.  After neo was started, UOP finally picked up after a few hours.
   At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most likely pre-renal in setting of
   hypotension during the procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to
   ATN (intrarenal).  FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other
   etiologies (though less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of
   depressed EF% versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent
   contrast administration.
   - turn off neo and see if he can maintain BP on his own
   - renal consult this AM
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4
   overnight. Likely febrile in setting of recent procedure. Hypotension,
   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning
   for possible sepsis.  UA is negative.
   - f/u blood cultures, urine cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Hyperbilirubinemia: Long-standing but bilirubin is very high at 2.7
   this am. Etiologies include [**Doctor Last Name **] syndrome, fatty liver and biliary
   stasis, CHF and biliary stasis, acalculous cholecystitis, gallstone
   cholecystitis. Patient sedated with propofol overnight given quick
   on/off for sedation. Patient received fentanyl and versed but was
   reportedly not well sedated during the procedure on this regimen,
   resulting in switch to propofol. Per discussion with pharmacy, OK to
   sedate with propofol temporarily overnight (12 hours) if extubation
   planned this AM.
   - f/u on direct and indirect bili
   - consider RUQ US
   - trend LFTs daily
   .
   # PUMP: Non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, thought to be viral in
   etiology. Likely has chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure (EF
   25% on [**9-28**].) Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC
   today with severe pulmonary hypertension. Patient received lasix 20 mg
   IV x1 in PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then
   held in the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were
   ~20 pts lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output.
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - fluid restriction, low Na diet, strict Is and Os, foley, daily
   weights
   - continue BB, digoxin
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient is s/p AICD placement for primary prevention of
   tachyarrythmias given non-ischemic cardiomyopathy EF of 25%. One
   episode of NSVT in the CCU.  Dig level 0.9 this am.
   - will need PA/lateral CXR once pt is extubated to check lead position
   - EP to interrogate pacer in AM
   - replete K > 4 Mg > 2
   - continue beta-blocker and digoxin
   .
   # CORONARIES: No known hx of CAD.
   - continue ASA, beta-blocker
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] in setting acute renal failure
   .
   # Asthma:
   - albuterol inhaler prn
   .
   # Anemia: Known iron deficiency anemia.
   - Trend Hct.
   - Continue iron supplements with bowel regimen and vitamin C once able
   to take PO.
   .
   # OSA:
   - restart/encourage nocturnal CPAP at home once extubated.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NPO for now
   Glycemic Control:  not on insulin
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2193-1-8**] 10:00 PM
   18 Gauge - [**2193-1-8**] 10:56 PM

   Stress ulcer:
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Need for restraints reviewed

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the ICU after failing to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He has a history of systolic and diastolic heart failure, and is currently intubated and sedated. The patient has developed hypotension, acute renal failure, fever, and hyperbilirubinemia. He is also experiencing respiratory acidosis and has a history of iron deficiency anemia.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, hypotension, and decreased urine output may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and he is experiencing oliguria, which may indicate AKI.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiomyopathy and heart failure may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, or cardiac tamponade.
4. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory acidosis and respiratory failure may lead to respiratory distress, respiratory arrest, or need for mechanical ventilation.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's hyperbilirubinemia and elevated liver enzymes may indicate liver dysfunction or cholestasis, which could lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, pancreatitis, or liver failure.
6. Infectious complications: The patient's fever and positive blood cultures may indicate a bacterial infection, which could lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, or death.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's non-ischemic cardiomyopathy and heart failure may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, or cardiac tamponade.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Monitoring for sepsis and AKI
* Managing cardiac complications with diuretics and vasopressors
* Weaning from mechanical ventilation and sedation
* Monitoring for respiratory complications and adjusting ventilator settings as needed
* Managing gastrointestinal complications with anti-emetics and antacids
* Monitoring for infectious complications and adjusting antibiotic therapy as needed
* Monitoring for cardiovascular complications and adjusting therapy as needed
* Providing nutritional support and managing glycemic control
* Managing lines and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

   sepsis given recent diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of
   keflex, fever noted on CCU admission, hypotension, and decreased urine
   output.  Patient was started on neo gtt for MAP>65.  Lasix gtt was
   held. PEEP was turned down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.
   - turn off neo this morning and see if pt can maintain BP on his own
   - extubate today if possible
   - hold placement of CVL for now given possible extubation this AM; will
   place if pressor requirements increase.
   - f/u blood and urine cultures
   - check  c. diff toxin assay
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cre up to 1.7 on admission and up to 2.1 this AM
   (baseline 1.1).  Patient relatively oliguric on admission to the CCU
   with only 40 ccs of dark urine output to 20 of IV lasix administered in
   the PACU.   After lasix gtt was started last night, UOP was close to
   zero.  After neo was started, UOP finally picked up after a few hours.
   At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most likely pre-renal in setting of
   hypotension during the procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to
   ATN (intrarenal).  FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other
   etiologies (though less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of
   depressed EF% versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent
   contrast administration.
   - turn off neo and see if he can maintain BP on his own
   - renal consult this AM
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4
   overnight. Likely febrile in setting of recent procedure. Hypotension,
   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning
   for possible sepsis.  UA is negative.
   - f/u blood cultures, urine cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # PUMP: Non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, thought to be viral in
   etiology. Likely has chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure (EF
   25% on [**9-28**].) Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC
   today with severe pulmonary hypertension. Patient received lasix 20 mg
   IV x1 in PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then
   held in the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were
   ~20 pts lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output.
   - hold lasix gtt for now

   - EP to interrogate pacer in AM

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 101.4Â°F, blood pressure of 124/64 mmHg, heart rate of 100 bpm, and respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is labile, with a systolic pressure of 70s mmHg on the arterial line, indicating relative hypotension. The etiology is unclear, but may be due to sedation/mechanical ventilation or sepsis.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated at 1.7 mg/dL, and urine output is decreased. The likely etiology is pre-renal, due to hypotension during the procedure, leading to ATN (intrarenal).
3. Fever: The patient's temperature is elevated at 101.4Â°F, likely due to recent procedure. Hypotension is concerning for possible sepsis.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated, with a PEEP of 8 cmH2O and FiO2 of 40%.
5. Cardiac Failure: The patient has non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, with an ejection fraction of 25%. He has chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure, with elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC.
6. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient's bilirubin level is elevated at 2.7 mg/dL, likely due to [**Doctor Last Name **] syndrome, fatty liver, or biliary stasis.
7. Anemia: The patient has known iron deficiency anemia, with a Hct of 36.9%.
8. OSA: The patient has a history of OSA, and will need to restart nocturnal CPAP at home once extubated.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Weaning off propofol and extubation if possible.
2. Turning off neo and monitoring the patient's blood pressure.
3. Holding lasix gtt and reevaluating the patient's urine output.
4. Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics.
5. Monitoring the patient's creatinine level and adjusting fluid management accordingly.
6. Trending LFTs daily to monitor the patient's liver function.
7. Restarting nocturnal CPAP at home once extubated.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He has a history of chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure, with an estimated ejection fraction of 25%. The patient is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a fever of 101.4Â°F, and has a history of cellulitis treated with 10 days of cephalexin.

The patient has been diagnosed with acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL and a urine output of 250cc/hr. He has also been diagnosed with hyperbilirubinemia, with a bilirubin level of 2.7 mg/dL, and is being treated with propofol for sedation.

The patient's cardiac status is grave, with a left ventricular stroke work capacity that is profoundly reduced. His morbid obesity and presumptive substance abuse problem make cardiac transplantation candidacy questionable. The patient is at risk for sepsis, with a fever and elevated white blood cell count, and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count put him at risk for sepsis, which could lead to organ failure and death.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and his urine output is low, indicating acute kidney injury. This could lead to chronic kidney disease and require dialysis.
3. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient's bilirubin level is elevated, which could lead to jaundice, pruritus, and liver dysfunction.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy and his current cardiac status put him at risk for cardiac arrhythmias, which could lead to sudden death.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, with a history of chronic respiratory acidosis and a current requirement for mechanical ventilation. This could lead to respiratory failure and death.
6. Infectious complications: The patient's history of cellulitis and his current antibiotic treatment put him at risk for infectious complications, such as bacteremia or pneumonia.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac status is compromised, with a history of chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure, and he is at risk for cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac tamponade or cardiac rupture.

Overall, the patient's condition is grave, and he requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment to prevent further complications.

   (baseline 1.1).  Patient relatively oliguric on admission to the CCU
   with only 40 ccs of dark urine output to 20 of IV lasix administered in
   the PACU.   After lasix gtt was started last night, UOP was close to
   zero.  After neo was started, UOP finally picked up after a few hours.
   At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most likely pre-renal in setting of
   hypotension during the procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to
   ATN (intrarenal).  FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other
   etiologies (though less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of
   depressed EF% versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent
   contrast administration.
   - turn off neo and see if he can maintain BP on his own
   - renal consult this AM
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4
   overnight. Likely febrile in setting of recent procedure. Hypotension,
   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning
   for possible sepsis.  UA is negative.
   - f/u blood cultures, urine cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # PUMP: Non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, thought to be viral in
   etiology. Likely has chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure (EF
   25% on [**9-28**].) Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC
   today with severe pulmonary hypertension. Patient received lasix 20 mg
   IV x1 in PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then
   held in the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were
   ~20 pts lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output.
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - fluid restriction, low Na diet, strict Is and Os, foley, daily
   weights
   - continue BB, digoxin
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient is s/p AICD placement for primary prevention of
   tachyarrythmias given non-ischemic cardiomyopathy EF of 25%. One
   episode of NSVT in the CCU.  Dig level 0.9 this am.
   - will need PA/lateral CXR once pt is extubated to check lead position
   - EP to interrogate pacer in AM
   - replete K > 4 Mg > 2
   - continue beta-blocker and digoxin
   .
   # CORONARIES: No known hx of CAD.
   - continue ASA, beta-blocker
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] in setting acute renal failure
   .
   # Hyperbilirubinemia: Long-standing but bilirubin is very high at 2.7
   this am. Etiologies include [**Doctor Last Name **] syndrome, fatty liver and biliary
   stasis, CHF and biliary stasis, acalculous cholecystitis, gallstone
   cholecystitis. Patient sedated with propofol overnight given quick
   on/off for sedation. Patient received fentanyl and versed but was
   reportedly not well sedated during the procedure on this regimen,
   resulting in switch to propofol. Per discussion with pharmacy, OK to
   sedate with propofol temporarily overnight (12 hours) if extubation
   planned this AM.
   - f/u on direct and indirect bili
   - consider RUQ US
   - trend LFTs daily
   .
   # Asthma:
   - albuterol inhaler prn
   .
   # Anemia: Known iron deficiency anemia.
   - Trend Hct.
   - Continue iron supplements with bowel regimen and vitamin C once able
   to take PO.
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) after failure to extubate following elective implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) placement and right heart catheterization.

The patient has been experiencing hypotension, with a blood pressure reading of 70s/40s, which was likely due to sedation, mechanical ventilation, or sepsis. He was started on neosulfonamide (neo) to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 65 mmHg.

The patient also has acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL on admission and 2.1 mg/dL this morning. He was oliguric initially, with only 40 mL of dark urine output, but his urine output increased to 250 mL/hr after neo was started.

The patient has a fever of 101.4Â°F, which is likely due to the recent procedure. He has also been experiencing respiratory acidosis, which was initially thought to be due to obesity hypoventilation syndrome, but subsequent arterial blood gas (ABG) results showed normal gas exchange.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin, creatinine, and bilirubin, which may indicate acute kidney injury, cardiac injury, or liver dysfunction.

The patient's medical history is significant for non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, known iron deficiency anemia, and asthma. He has also been experiencing symptoms of hyperbilirubinemia, which may be due to various etiologies such as Gilbert syndrome, fatty liver, or biliary stasis.

The patient's current medications include beta-blockers, digoxin, and diuretics. He has also been receiving sedation with propofol and has been intubated.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure reading of 70s/40s is concerning, and he may require further management with vasopressors or fluids.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he may require further management with diuretics or dialysis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis may worsen if he is not extubated soon, and he may require further management with mechanical ventilation.
4. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count may indicate sepsis, which requires prompt management with antibiotics and fluid resuscitation.
5. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient's elevated bilirubin level may indicate liver dysfunction, which requires further evaluation and management.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Weaning off propofol and sedation.
2. Weaning off mechanical ventilation and extubation.
3. Managing hypotension with vasopressors or fluids.
4. Managing acute kidney injury with diuretics or dialysis.
5. Managing respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation.
6. Managing sepsis with antibiotics and fluid resuscitation.
7. Managing hyperbilirubinemia with further evaluation and management.

The patient's potential discharge diagnoses include:

1. Non-ischemic cardiomyopathy.
2. Acute kidney injury.
3. Respiratory failure.
4. Sepsis.
5. Hyperbilirubinemia.

The patient's potential treatment options include:

1. Vasopressors or fluids for hypotension.
2. Diuretics or dialysis for acute kidney injury.
3. Mechanical ventilation for respiratory failure.
4. Antibiotics and fluid resuscitation for sepsis.
5. Further evaluation and management for hyperbilirubinemia.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the ICU after failure to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He is intubated and sedated, with a history of systolic and diastolic heart failure, chronic respiratory acidosis, and morbid obesity. The patient has developed acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL, and is oliguric with a urine output of 40 mL in 24 hours. He also has a fever, with a temperature of 101.4Â°F, and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Potential medical complications:

1. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is oliguric, which increases the risk of AKI.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy and is at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and is at risk for respiratory failure, particularly if his underlying lung disease worsens.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulation therapy and his history of gastrointestinal bleeding increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Infection: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of infection, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
7. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is oliguric, which increases the risk of renal failure.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy and his current cardiac status increase the risk of cardiovascular complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.

Assessment and plan:

The patient will be closely monitored for any signs of deterioration, and his condition will be reassessed regularly. He will continue to receive broad-spectrum antibiotics, and his antibiotic regimen will be adjusted based on the results of his cultures. He will also receive supportive care, including mechanical ventilation, sedation, and pain management. His renal function will be closely monitored, and he will be treated with diuretics and other medications as necessary to manage his fluid status. His cardiac function will also be closely monitored, and he will be treated with medications and other therapies as necessary to manage his cardiac status.

   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization on
   [**1-8**]. Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid
   obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume
   overload from patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading
   to elevated elastic pressures. ABG initially showed chronic respiratory
   acidosis with appropriate metabolic compensation, may be due to obesity

   severe pulmonary hypertension; Patient received lasix 20 mg IV x1 in
   PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then held in
   the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were ~20 pts
   lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output. On [**1-9**], UOP
   briskly responded to brief time on phenylephrine.  Patient was put on

   - patient with excellent urine output; can diurese gently as plan
   regarding heart becomes clear
   .

   2.1 on [**1-9**] (baseline 1.1). Improving to 1.7 today  Patient relatively
   oliguric on admission to the CCU with only 40 ccs of dark urine output
   to 20 of IV lasix administered in the PACU.   After lasix gtt was
   started last night, UOP was close to zero.  After neo was started, UOP
   finally picked up after a few hours.  At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most
   likely, his ARF was pre-renal in setting of hypotension during the
   procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to ATN (intrarenal).
   FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other etiologies (though

   versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent contrast

   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy and a history of cocaine use, who was admitted to the ICU after failing to extubate following elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He has severe biventricular systolic dysfunction, likely due to prior cocaine use, and is at high risk for cardiac transplantation. The patient has a history of substance abuse, morbid obesity, and chronic respiratory acidosis.

Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Failure: The patient has severe biventricular systolic dysfunction, which is likely due to prior cocaine use. This has led to profound biventricular systolic dysfunction and exacerbated chronic respiratory acidosis.
2. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient had an elevated creatinine level of 1.7 on admission, which has improved to 1.7 today. The ARF is likely pre-renal in origin, secondary to hypotension during the procedure.
3. Fever: The patient has a temperature of 101.2Â°F on arrival to the ICU, which has spiked to 101.4Â°F on [**1-8**]. The likely cause is aspiration pneumonitis or pneumonia.
4. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient has a high bilirubin level of 2.7 on [**1-8**], which is likely due to congestive hepatopathy.
5. Hypotension: The patient had a blood pressure of 90-100/40-50 mmHg on arrival to the ICU, which has resolved with the placement of an arterial line and administration of vasopressors.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to his recent procedure, fever, and elevated white blood cell count.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has a high risk of developing pneumonia due to his recent aspiration pneumonitis and fever.
3. Cardiac Arrhythmias: The patient has a history of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia and is at high risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias due to his cardiomyopathy.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient has chronic respiratory acidosis and is at high risk of developing respiratory failure due to his morbid obesity and cardiomyopathy.

Plan:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected aspiration pneumonitis or pneumonia.
2. Monitor the patient's blood cultures, urine cultures, and CXR for signs of infection.
3. Continue to manage the patient's cardiac failure with diuretics, vasodilators, and inotropes as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust diuretic therapy accordingly.
5. Continue to manage the patient's hyperbilirubinemia with trend liver enzymes and consider cholestyramine therapy.
6. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust vasopressor therapy as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust anti-arrhythmic therapy as needed.
8. Consider cardiac catheterization to further evaluate the patient's coronary arteries and cardiac function.

   Assessment and Plan
   24 yo M with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to CCU after failure
   to extubate s/p elective AICD placement and right heart cath.
   .
   # CHF, systolic and exacerbated. profound biventricular systolic
   dysfunction, presumably secondary to prior heavy cocaine use in year
   prior to CHF diagnosis.  Also possibly viral (was tested at time of
   diagnosis and only positive for RSV) or alcoholic (patient endorses
   weekend binges at most). TTE of [**1-9**] shows EF of 10% that may be an
   overestimate. His situation is grave, as his LV stroke work capacity is
   so profoundly reduced.  His morbid obesity and history of substance
   abuse makes cardiac transplantation candidacy questionable.
   PLAN per Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   -  attempt a definitive dx before implementing maximal therapy
   -  Thererfore we will do left and right heart cath, endomyocardial bx,
   and pulmonary arterioloar vasodilator trila irf PVR is > 4 [**Doctor Last Name 2576**] units.
   -  Thereafter we will leave SGC in place and do tailored therapy
   - continue bb, digoxin, fluid restriction, and when appropriate, a low
   Na diet
   .
   # Failure to extubate: Patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU
   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization on
   [**1-8**]. Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid
   obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume
   overload from patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading
   to elevated elastic pressures. ABG initially showed chronic respiratory
   acidosis with appropriate metabolic compensation, may be due to obesity
   hypoventilation/Pickwickian syndrome, but repeat ABG showed normal
   gas.  Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC [**1-8**] with
   severe pulmonary hypertension; Patient received lasix 20 mg IV x1 in
   PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then held in
   the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were ~20 pts
   lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output. On [**1-9**], UOP
   briskly responded to brief time on phenylephrine.  Patient was put on
   was transitioned from AC to CPAP on [**1-9**].
   - modify vent settings as needed
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - wean ventilator as tolerated
   - patient with excellent urine output; can diurese gently as plan
   regarding heart becomes clear
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Resolving. Cre up to 1.7 on admission and up to
   2.1 on [**1-9**] (baseline 1.1). Improving to 1.7 today  Patient relatively
   oliguric on admission to the CCU with only 40 ccs of dark urine output
   to 20 of IV lasix administered in the PACU.   After lasix gtt was
   started last night, UOP was close to zero.  After neo was started, UOP
   finally picked up after a few hours.  At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most
   likely, his ARF was pre-renal in setting of hypotension during the
   procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to ATN (intrarenal).
   FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other etiologies (though
   less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of depressed EF%
   versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent contrast
   administration.
   -  hold lasix gtt for now
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4 on [**1-8**].
   Likely febrile in setting of recent procedure with traumatic
   intubation. Most likely aspiration pneumonitis or (less likely)
   pneumonia). Sputum gram stain with several species. Hypotension,
   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning
   for possible sepsis.  UA negative. Blood cx pending. RUQ US: No
   gallbladder, no cholecystitis
   - f/u blood cultures, urine cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx ( vanc and levo). Likely switch to
   regular vanc dosing from level-dosing. Receiving 1.5 g this AM.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient is s/p AICD placement for primary prevention of
   tachyarrythmias given non-ischemic cardiomyopathy EF of 10%
   (presently). One episode of NSVT in the CCU.  Dig level 0.9 on [**1-9**].
   - will need PA/lateral CXR once pt is extubated to check lead position
   - replete K > 4 Mg > 2
   - continue beta-blocker and digoxin
   .
   # Hyperbilirubinemia: Long-standing but bilirubin is very high at 2.7
   on [**1-8**]. Etiologies include obstructive and infiltrative disease
   including congestive hepatopathy, fatty liver and biliary stasis,
   fibrosis and biliary stasis, and post-hepatic obstruction. Given fever,
   was ruled out for cholecystitis. This is most likely congestive.
   - trend liver enzymes
   .
   # Hypotension: Resolved. Patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After
   arriving on the CCU floor, non-invasive approach revealed BP in the
   90-100s/40s.  However, patient had no UOP to lasix bolus and gtt, so
   A-line was placed. Placement of A-line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating
   relative hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical
   ventilation which are more likely given the acute change, sepsis given
   recent diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of keflex, fever
   noted on CCU admission, or cardiogenic which are less likely given the
   acute time course of events, i.e., his BP was good prior to the
   procedure.  Patient was started on neo gtt for MAP>65.  Lasix gtt was
   held. PEEP was turned down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.
   Patient weaned from Neo in the AM of [**1-9**].
   - decrease and wean off propofol as possible
   - f/u blood and urine cultures
   - check  c. diff toxin assay
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and levo)
   .
   # CORONARIES: No known hx of CAD.
   - cath will be definitive
   - continue ASA, beta-blocker
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] in setting acute renal failure
   .
   # Asthma:
   - ipratropium prn or albuterol
   .
   # Anemia: Known iron deficiency anemia.
   - Trend Hct.
   - Continue iron supplements with bowel regimen and vitamin C once able
   to take PO.
   .
   # OSA:
   - restart/encourage nocturnal CPAP at home once extubated.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the ICU after failure to extubate following elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He has a history of cocaine use, viral (RSV) and possible alcohol-related cardiomyopathy. The patient's condition is grave, with severe biventricular systolic dysfunction, and his left ventricular stroke work capacity is profoundly reduced.

The patient's recent events include:

* Spontaneous breathing trial off propofol, which was unsuccessful due to agitation and desaturation
* Placement of a nasogastric tube (NGT) for medication administration
* Transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE) showing EF <20%, but Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] estimated EF to be likely single digits
* RUQ ultrasound (US) showing non-visualization of the gallbladder, suggesting gallbladder agenesis
* Cardiac catheterization planned for the next day with minimal dye load
* Patient's condition is complicated by:
	+ Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
	+ Acute renal failure, which is resolving
	+ Fever, which is likely due to aspiration pneumonitis or pneumonia
	+ Hypotension, which is likely due to sedation/intubation, sepsis, or cardiogenic causes
	+ Hyperbilirubinemia, which is likely due to congestive hepatopathy
	+ Anemia, which is likely due to iron deficiency
	+ OSA, which is likely due to morbid obesity

Potential medical complications:

* Pneumonia or aspiration pneumonitis
* Sepsis or septic shock
* Cardiac tamponade or cardiogenic shock
* Respiratory failure or respiratory arrest
* Acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease
* Liver failure or liver disease
* Anemia or bleeding complications
* OSA or sleep apnea
* Cardiac arrhythmias or tachyarrhythmias
* Cardiac transplantation or heart failure

Plan:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and sedation as needed
* Monitor for signs of pneumonia or aspiration pneumonitis
* Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics and antifungals
* Monitor for signs of sepsis or septic shock
* Plan cardiac catheterization and endomyocardial biopsy
* Consider cardiac transplantation evaluation once stabilized
* Monitor for signs of liver failure or liver disease
* Continue iron supplements and vitamin C
* Restart nocturnal CPAP at home once extubated
* Monitor for signs of anemia or bleeding complications
* Monitor for signs of OSA or sleep apnea
* Continue beta-blocker and digoxin therapy
* Monitor for signs of cardiac arrhythmias or tachyarrhythmias

   Assessment and Plan
   24 yo M with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to CCU after failure
   to extubate s/p elective AICD placement and right heart cath.
   .
   # CHF, systolic and exacerbated. profound biventricular systolic
   dysfunction, presumably secondary to prior heavy cocaine use in year
   prior to CHF diagnosis.  Also possibly viral (was tested at time of
   diagnosis and only positive for RSV) or alcoholic (patient endorses
   weekend binges at most). TTE of [**1-9**] shows EF of 10% that may be an
   overestimate. His situation is grave, as his LV stroke work capacity is
   so profoundly reduced.  His morbid obesity and history of substance
   abuse makes cardiac transplantation candidacy questionable.
   PLAN per Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   -  attempt a definitive dx before implementing maximal therapy
   -  Thererfore we will do left and right heart cath, endomyocardial bx,
   and pulmonary arterioloar vasodilator trila irf PVR is > 4 [**Doctor Last Name 2576**] units.
   -  Thereafter we will leave SGC in place and do tailored therapy
   - continue bb, digoxin, fluid restriction, and when appropriate, a low
   Na diet
   .
   # Failure to extubate: Patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU
   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization on
   [**1-8**]. Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid
   obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume
   overload from patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading
   to elevated elastic pressures. ABG initially showed chronic respiratory
   acidosis with appropriate metabolic compensation, may be due to obesity
   hypoventilation/Pickwickian syndrome, but repeat ABG showed normal
   gas.  Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC [**1-8**] with
   severe pulmonary hypertension; Patient received lasix 20 mg IV x1 in
   PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then held in
   the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were ~20 pts
   lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output. On [**1-9**], UOP
   briskly responded to brief time on phenylephrine.  Patient was put on
   was transitioned from AC to CPAP on [**1-9**].
   - modify vent settings as needed
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - wean ventilator as tolerated
   - patient with excellent urine output; can diurese gently as plan
   regarding heart becomes clear
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Resolving. Cre up to 1.7 on admission and up to
   2.1 on [**1-9**] (baseline 1.1). Improving to 1.7 today  Patient relatively
   oliguric on admission to the CCU with only 40 ccs of dark urine output
   to 20 of IV lasix administered in the PACU.   After lasix gtt was
   started last night, UOP was close to zero.  After neo was started, UOP
   finally picked up after a few hours.  At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most
   likely, his ARF was pre-renal in setting of hypotension during the
   procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to ATN (intrarenal).
   FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other etiologies (though
   less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of depressed EF%
   versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent contrast
   administration.
   -  hold lasix gtt for now
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4 on [**1-8**].
   Likely febrile in setting of recent procedure with traumatic
   intubation. Most likely aspiration pneumonitis or (less likely)
   pneumonia). Sputum gram stain with several species. Hypotension,
   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning
   for possible sepsis.  UA negative. Blood cx pending. RUQ US: No
   gallbladder, no cholecystitis
   - f/u blood cultures, urine cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx ( vanc and levo). Likely switch to
   regular vanc dosing from level-dosing. Receiving 1.5 g this AM.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient is s/p AICD placement for primary prevention of
   tachyarrythmias given non-ischemic cardiomyopathy EF of 10%
   (presently). One episode of NSVT in the CCU.  Dig level 0.9 on [**1-9**].
   - will need PA/lateral CXR once pt is extubated to check lead position
   - replete K > 4 Mg > 2
   - continue beta-blocker and digoxin
   .
   # Hyperbilirubinemia: Long-standing but bilirubin is very high at 2.7
   on [**1-8**]. Etiologies include obstructive and infiltrative disease
   including congestive hepatopathy, fatty liver and biliary stasis,
   fibrosis and biliary stasis, and post-hepatic obstruction. Given fever,
   was ruled out for cholecystitis. This is most likely congestive.
   - trend liver enzymes
   .
   # Hypotension: Resolved. Patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After
   arriving on the CCU floor, non-invasive approach revealed BP in the
   90-100s/40s.  However, patient had no UOP to lasix bolus and gtt, so
   A-line was placed. Placement of A-line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating
   relative hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical
   ventilation which are more likely given the acute change, sepsis given
   recent diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of keflex, fever
   noted on CCU admission, or cardiogenic which are less likely given the
   acute time course of events, i.e., his BP was good prior to the
   procedure.  Patient was started on neo gtt for MAP>65.  Lasix gtt was
   held. PEEP was turned down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.
   Patient weaned from Neo in the AM of [**1-9**].

   ABD US [**1-9**]
   Evaluation is slightly limited by patient's
   size. Within this limitation, the liver echotexture is unremarkable.
   There
   is no intra- or extra-hepatic biliary ductal dilatation, and the common
   bile
   duct measures 6 mm. Main portal vein is patent with hepatopetal flow.
   There
   is no ascites. The gallbladder is not identified. The spleen measures
   11.7
   cm.
   Microbiology: [**10-9**] Cx pending (urine, blood, sputum)
   Sputum Gram Stain
         >25 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field.
         2+   (1-5 per 1000X FIELD):   GRAM POSITIVE COCCI.
                                       IN PAIRS, CHAINS, AND CLUSTERS.
         2+   (1-5 per 1000X FIELD):   GRAM NEGATIVE ROD(S).
         1+    (<1 per 1000X FIELD):   GRAM NEGATIVE DIPLOCOCCI.
   Assessment and Plan
   24 yo M with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to CCU after failure
   to extubate s/p elective AICD placement and right heart cath.
   .
   # CHF, systolic and exacerbated. profound biventricular systolic
   dysfunction, presumably secondary to prior heavy cocaine use in year
   prior to CHF diagnosis.  Also possibly viral (was tested at time of
   diagnosis and only positive for RSV) or alcoholic (patient endorses
   weekend binges at most). TTE of [**1-9**] shows EF of 10% that may be an
   overestimate. His situation is grave, as his LV stroke work capacity is
   so profoundly reduced.  His morbid obesity and history of substance
   abuse makes cardiac transplantation candidacy questionable.
   PLAN per Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   -  attempt a definitive dx before implementing maximal therapy
   -  Thererfore we will do left and right heart cath, endomyocardial bx,
   and pulmonary arterioloar vasodilator trila irf PVR is > 4 [**Doctor Last Name 2576**] units.
   -  Thereafter we will leave SGC in place and do tailored therapy
   - continue bb, digoxin, fluid restriction, and when appropriate, a low
   Na diet
   .
   # Failure to extubate: Patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU
   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization on
   [**1-8**]. Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid
   obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume
   overload from patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading
   to elevated elastic pressures. ABG initially showed chronic respiratory
   acidosis with appropriate metabolic compensation, may be due to obesity
   hypoventilation/Pickwickian syndrome, but repeat ABG showed normal
   gas.  Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC [**1-8**] with
   severe pulmonary hypertension; Patient received lasix 20 mg IV x1 in
   PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then held in
   the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were ~20 pts
   lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output. On [**1-9**], UOP
   briskly responded to brief time on phenylephrine.  Patient was put on
   was transitioned from AC to CPAP on [**1-9**].
   - modify vent settings as needed
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - wean ventilator as tolerated
   - patient with excellent urine output; can diurese gently as plan
   regarding heart becomes clear
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Resolving. Cre up to 1.7 on admission and up to
   2.1 on [**1-9**] (baseline 1.1). Improving to 1.7 today  Patient relatively
   oliguric on admission to the CCU with only 40 ccs of dark urine output
   to 20 of IV lasix administered in the PACU.   After lasix gtt was
   started last night, UOP was close to zero.  After neo was started, UOP
   finally picked up after a few hours.  At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most
   likely, his ARF was pre-renal in setting of hypotension during the
   procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to ATN (intrarenal).
   FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other etiologies (though
   less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of depressed EF%
   versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent contrast
   administration.
   -  hold lasix gtt for now
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4 on [**1-8**].
   Likely febrile in setting of recent procedure with traumatic
   intubation. Most likely aspiration pneumonitis or (less likely)
   pneumonia). Sputum gram stain with several species. Hypotension,
   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning
   for possible sepsis.  UA negative. Blood cx pending. RUQ US: No
   gallbladder, no cholecystitis
   - f/u blood cultures, urine cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx ( vanc and levo). Likely switch to
   regular vanc dosing from level-dosing. Receiving 1.5 g this AM.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient is s/p AICD placement for primary prevention of
   tachyarrythmias given non-ischemic cardiomyopathy EF of 10%
   (presently). One episode of NSVT in the CCU.  Dig level 0.9 on [**1-9**].
   - will need PA/lateral CXR once pt is extubated to check lead position
   - replete K > 4 Mg > 2
   - continue beta-blocker and digoxin
   .
   # Hyperbilirubinemia: Long-standing but bilirubin is very high at 2.7
   on [**1-8**]. Etiologies include obstructive and infiltrative disease
   including congestive hepatopathy, fatty liver and biliary stasis,
   fibrosis and biliary stasis, and post-hepatic obstruction. Given fever,
   was ruled out for cholecystitis. This is most likely congestive.
   - trend liver enzymes
   .
   # Hypotension: Resolved. Patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After
   arriving on the CCU floor, non-invasive approach revealed BP in the
   90-100s/40s.  However, patient had no UOP to lasix bolus and gtt, so
   A-line was placed. Placement of A-line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating
   relative hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical
   ventilation which are more likely given the acute change, sepsis given
   recent diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of keflex, fever
   noted on CCU admission, or cardiogenic which are less likely given the
   acute time course of events, i.e., his BP was good prior to the
   procedure.  Patient was started on neo gtt for MAP>65.  Lasix gtt was
   held. PEEP was turned down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.
   Patient weaned from Neo in the AM of [**1-9**].
   - decrease and wean off propofol as possible
   - f/u blood and urine cultures
   - check  c. diff toxin assay
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and levo)
   .
   # CORONARIES: No known hx of CAD.
   - cath will be definitive
   - continue ASA, beta-blocker
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] in setting acute renal failure
   .
   # Asthma:
   - ipratropium prn or albuterol
   .
   # Anemia: Known iron deficiency anemia.
   - Trend Hct.
   - Continue iron supplements with bowel regimen and vitamin C once able
   to take PO.
   .
   # OSA:
   - restart/encourage nocturnal CPAP at home once extubated.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
